name: Massive Damage
description: When a creature takes damage equal to or greater than half its Hit Point Maximum from a single source of damage, it must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or suffer a random effect from the System Shock table. This rule makes large hits more dangerous and creates dramatic combat moments.

mechanics.trigger: A creature takes damage from a single source equal to or greater than half its Hit Point Maximum (before the damage is applied)
mechanics.onSuccess: No additional effect beyond the damage taken
mechanics.onFailure: Roll on the System Shock table (1d10)

systemShockTable.effect: The creature drops to 0 Hit Points
The creature has the Stunned condition until the end of its next turn
The creature can't take Reactions, and its Speed is halved, until the end of its next turn
The creature can't take Reactions until the end of its next turn

limitations: The threshold is half the creature's Hit Point Maximum, not half its current Hit Points
Each instance of damage is evaluated separately; multiple smaller hits do not combine to trigger this rule
Creatures immune to the Stunned condition are still affected by other results on the table

interactions: High-damage single-hit attacks (such as Disintegrate, critical hits with Sneak Attack, or falling from great heights) are the most common triggers
Creatures with low HP maximums (e.g., commoners, low-CR creatures) will trigger this frequently, adding lethality to encounters
The Stunned condition from result 2-3 is extremely punishing as it causes auto-failed Strength and Dexterity saves and grants Advantage to attackers
Constitution saving throw proficiency and high Constitution scores make characters more resilient against this rule
This interacts with the Relentless Endurance trait (half-orcs) which can prevent the drop to 0 HP from result 1
